oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Vern Gosdin Interview - Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording of an interview with Vern Gosdin (performer) conducted by Biff Collie.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Vern Gosdin; Biff Collie
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Vern Gosdin talks about dreaming a singer -- (00:40) Gosdin talks about being one of eleven kids being raised on a rock farm and discovering his father's moon shining -- (02:17) Gosdin talks about his families musical talents and eventual professional work -- (02:53) Gosdin talks about the first time he sang in front of a crowd (a local talent contest) -- (03:38) Biff Collie and Gosdin talk about his first guitar being gifted to him and his father's disagreement with music -- (04:34) Gosdin talks about why he started writing music and his fascination with country stars -- (05:21) Collie challenges Gosdin to name all of his siblings -- (06:12) Collie and Gosdin talk about first talent show in-depth -- (07:06) Gosdin and Collie discuss emanating who they heard on the Opry and Gosdin talks about picking up various instruments -- (08:01) Gosdin talks about The Golden State Boys group he joined immediately after moving to California and how his first album was rock and roll -- (09:02) Gosdin talks about continuing to work with the Golden State Boys and his idea of the loss of bluegrass -- (10:54) Gosdin talks about being a glass maker in Atlanta Georgia and moving to Nashville to record -- (13:01) Gosdin and Collie talk about the Gosdin Family Gospel Show -- (14:32) Collie says phrases for Gosdin to reflect on starting with a bar he owned -- (15:50) Gosdin recalls his 1970 Philippine Tour and rush of the shows -- (16:58) Gosdin talks about his driver during the Philippine Tour fighting in a field to settle their differences -- (17:54) Gosdin talks about the Blue Room and seeing The Lumen Brothers -- (18:54) Gosdin talks about Christmas 1981 with George Jones and meeting him on tour in London, England -- (20:16) Gosdin says who he'd enjoy recording with -- (20:52) Collie brings up how quotable Gosdin is while reading critics reviews -- (22:06) Gosdin expresses how he does not like that people think they need to put him on a pedestal -- (22:58) "Yesterday's gone" is talked about -- (23:13) "Til the End" and Gosdin's sons are discussed -- (23:38) The recording of "Never My Love" is talked about -- (24:23) "Dream of Me" is talked about how it almost was not recorded -- (24:55) "Break My Mind" is briefly touched on -- (25:15) "If You're Gonna Do Me Wrong, Do Me Right" was wrote for Gosdin's wife
